editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: ¶ One and thyrtye Epigrammes wherein are brieflye touched ſo manye abuſes, that maye and ought to be put away. Compiled and Imprinted by Robert Crowley, dwellinge in Elye rentes. in Holburne. Anno domini. 1550.
div.q: i. Cor. xiiii. What ſo euer ye do, let the ſame be done to edifie wythall.
Gala vi. If I ſhoulde ſtudye to pleaſe men: than coulde I not be the ſeruaunt of Chriſte.

lg.l: Now if I do the worldlinges
I take all the wyſe men
ſtyll in their ſynne to dwell:
Iohn. iii.He accounteth them no better
Wherefore he bade me bid them
He hath not written to them
Excepte it be to tell them
They ſhall be ſure and certayne
Mat. vii.no pearles maye be caſte,
But when they heare their fault
ſuche men as do them tell,Luke. v.
To theſe men am I ſente
and theſe I truſte will take

epigraph.q: He that is of God, heareth the worde of God.

div.head: ¶ The table of the cōtentes of thys boke.

list.head: L
list.item: Of Laye men that take tythes

div.head: Of Abbayes.
div.l: That the people wyll not ſe
Nor yet to be prouided for
but ſtyll in vayne to craue.

div.head: Of Alehouſes
div.l: That they ſtande in mens waye
whan they ſhoulde to churche go.
And than ſuche as loue not
no dore ſtandeth vp,A cōmendation of London.
tyll the daye be at an ende?
Not ſo well as he doeth
from the carte to the mowe.
Mat. xiiiBut he doeth make holye

div.head: Of Allayes.
div.l: A diſpraiſe of London.But in London (alas)
as an arte to lyue by.
Well I wyll ſaye no more
for of god they are not,
that be agaynſte kynde,Allayes agaynſte kynde.
whan they come to my mind.
and yet to worcke they are able.
Why beſtowe ye not the riches
To the profit of the Citye
For the charitie of rich men
It is a packe of people
that ſeke after mede.Loke the diffinitiō of a citye you that be ſerued
But for the wealth of ye commons
Where euerye man is for him ſelfe

div.head: Of Almes houſes.
div.l: By a Spittle houſe not farre from
For a Lordely houſe was builte
Do ye begge by the waye
and haue a houſe for a kynge?
And lye and dye in corners
And whan we craue of them
none ſuch crueltie haue I ſene

div.head: Of Baylife Arrantes.
div.l: And toke in hande to excuſe them
And when he ſhould warne a queſt
that woulde make him no cheare.
But when he metie his frendes
than woulde he ſaye but hem.
But ſuch as had no cheare
The baylifes hadlandeYe muſt geue him ſome thynge.
By ſuch as ſhoulde ſerue them:

div.head: Of Beggers.
div.l: i. Tim iiiThen ought they to faſte
Of two beggersthat vnder an hedge ſate
and as redde as any bloud
I would not haue it healed
That we let them nor heate
of a begger that was lame,Of an other begger.
if it were not the ſame.
wyth the cuppe in hys hande.
he ſhoulde be a good huſbande.
For I gate but .xvi.d. to daye
Go fyll me this quarte pot
Yet ceſſe not to gyue to all

div.head: Of Bearbaytynge.
div.l: And yet me thynke thoſe men
a man ſhall not fayle,Pariſe garden
To find two or thre hundredes
That the pore ought to haue

div.head: Of Brawlers.
div.l: I thinke he wyll hange in hell.

div.head: Of Blaſphemous ſwerers.
div.l: In the houſe of that manne
What ſo euer ye adde more
By the croſſe of the mouſe fote
And ſome ſweare by the deuell

div.head: Of the colier of Croydon.
div.l: IT is ſayde that in Croydon
But in the order of knighthode
For whan none but pore coliars
and had fewe ſackes to tale.
A lode that of late yeres
For men thynke he is coſen

div.head: Of Commotioners.
div.l: To kil ye ſtrength of thoſe humors
When the ſwerde wyll not helpe
and lette them of their wyll.
And that muſte be by cheriſhynge
as it is playne to ſe:
When the hertes of the people
For than there canne be found
haue not broughte vs ſo lowe,
And I truſte to ſe healthe agayne
Be not nowe nere at hande

div.head: Of commen drunkardes.
div.l: that do youre tyme paſſe.Eſaye. v.
Woe be to you, ſayeth he,
To fyll your ſelues with drincke
But if he were nowe liuynge
He wold ſay this of our drunkards
Well,i. Cor. i. ſainte Paule doeth warne
all that be of pure mynde
where ſo euer they do them finde.
Se ye neyther eate nor drincke

div.head: Of commune Liars.
div.l: But thys delite will be ſorowe
I feare me at the laſte,
Whan the liar for hys liynge

div.head: Of Dicears.
div.l: To auoid and fle dice (my ſon)
Some menne it hath ſette vp
or elſe his owne to ſpende.
For be they two or mo,
Wherof they thyncke they nede not
that though dyrynge were no ſin,
Yet the othes that they ſwere
then wyl he pour it oute

div.head: Of double benificed men.
div.l: And as he turned the boke,
Than ſayde he to him ſelfe
with the power of the kynge
If it may like your grace (quod he)
I repente me of all yll:
wil you haue your benifices ſtyl?
If your grace do me righte (ꝙ he)
I muſt haue them my life tyme,
and let al thyngis be done
For ſyth thou arte a ſtoute prieſt

div.head: Of the Exchecker
div.l: IN the weſte parte of Europe
That had a courte for receyte,
But the miniſters for that Court,
Take brybes to beare wt ſuche mē
At the laſte to the kynge,
Becauſe you dyd beare wyth them
what ſhall wyth them be done.
But well I wot they deſerued,

div.head: Of Fatterars.
div.l: when the other is not ſo.
ii. Re. iii.when the flatteryng frend,
I do not doubt but he would,
haue out of his waye ſterte.
Or at the leaſte he would not,
As to be embraced of him,
and on his dagger to dye.
Whych thynge may at the lengthe
Robyn red breaſt wyll come hom •
to you and be verye bolde.

div.head: Of Foles.
div.l: Is better than an olde kyng
Whan the fole in his riches
Some foles there be of nature
But do conceiue in their thought
That they them ſelues be wiſeſt
Theſe foles wyll heare no mans
And whatſoeuer they thē ſelues do
And whan they come in place
No man ſhall haue time to ſpeake,
Of theyr owne dedis and goodis,
If ye tell them of theyr fautes,
Ye muſte ſaye as they ſaye,
In fyne ye muſt prayſe them
And how ſo euer they do,
If ye tell them of knowledg,
For the loſſe of vayne toyes,
And then if ye reaſone farre,

div.head: Of Foreſtallers.
div.l: So that now we do paye,
For the fryſe we haue bought,
is bought ere it do growe
Can haue nought of our tythis,
And the old tenaunt muſt pay well
And where the father payd a penye
The ſonne muſt paye ten pounde
Leaſte the clarke of the market
i. Cor. x.Se that amonge you

div.head: Of Godleſſe men.
div.l: there were men of wicked hert,Pſal. viii
let vs take our owne waye.
and nought in all theyr wayes
That they thyncke there is no god
For to do the thynge that good is
if he were in theſe dayes,
And then they call that yll good,
what woulde Dauid ſaye to this?
But I knowe that good Eſay,
to them that in do call.
That thyng good that euell is
If they fynde a thynge wrytten
they wyll not ſtycke to deny.
And ſay they wyll make merie here
If theſe menne be not godles
Well, the cauſe is the Lordes
they ſhall fynde him to ſtrong.

div.head: Of Idle perſons
div.l: As by the ſtorie of Sodome,
But that we may come nere,
To breake the peace of prynces,
the Idlenes of prieſtis hath done
But the ſame dyd fyrſt ſprynge.
for they ar cōmitted to your charge
Or els in readynge or hearyng
woulde ſe men ſet a worke,
Which beīg wrought wt in ye realme
eche man might get his bread.

div.head: ¶ Of inuenters of ſtraūge newes.
div.l: What the kynge and hys counſell,
Yea,We ſawe the experience of thys of late. ſometyme they cauſe

div.head: ¶ Of Lay mē that take tithes, and prieſtes that vſe their tythes priuatelye.
div.l: For ſeing he made that priuate
Thoſe pore men that by the tythes
And bicauſe he ſhewed no mercye,
no mercye ſhall he haue,Iacob. ii.

div.head: Of Leaſemongers.
div.l: I will ſ • nd for a preacher
Whoe ſayde they had learned thys,

div.head: Of Marchauntes.
div.l: And leaue farmes to ſuch men
To ſuche men as muſte haue them
thoughe it be to their payne.
Howe they leaue of their trade
And thus I ſaye to them
and true they ſhall it fynde,
Iacob. ii.as ſaynte Iames doeth wytnes.

div.head: ¶ Of men that haue diuers offices
div.l: Yet were there ſome that did
But we reade not of anye
To haue two offices at once
That ſeketh not by all meanes
But Chriſte ſhal ſay to theſe menne
Ye that ſought to be rulers
That ye muſte leaue youre offices

div.head: Of Nice wyues.
div.l: That the gate and the garmentEccle. xi
What ſhold we thynk of the womē
then in London wines this day
and if the gate and the garmentis,
Our wyues do paſſe theyr whoris,
I thyncke the Iewe, neuer ſaw.
Then fyne geare on the forehead,
Though it coſt a crown or two.
what then? they maye not ſtycke.
If theyr heyre wyl not take colour
And laye it oute in tuſſockis,
And ſome bye waſtes of wyre
Leaſte I haue but ſmall thanckes
I truſte wyll take my parte,
ſhall not come nye my hert.
I haue tolde them but trueth
let them ſaye what they wyll,
I haue ſayde they be whore like

div.head: Of Obſtinate Papiſtes
div.l: That he ſtale out of England
and thus is one man three.
Where wyth him in fryes cotis,
Or els I would they were,
For whylſe they be in England,
they do but lyue in hope.
they haue ſette ſo much by.

div.head: Of rente rayſers.
div.l: he ſayde he did not paſſe.
That wyth hys owne he myghte,
Luke. xviOf a voyce that he hearde

div.head: Of Vayne wryters, vaine talkers and vaine hearers.
div.l: ye ſhall geue a rekeninge.Mat. xii.

div.head: Of vnſaciable purchaſers.
div.l: And as he paſte by a paſture
Woulde they haue me to purchaſe
and kepe greate houſe to?Luk. xiiii
I can not tell (quod the boye)
But they ſaye that ye purchaſe
the Deuill, his dame and all.

div.head: Of Vſurers.
div.l: And yet wold faine haue liued
Of thys lande he made ſale
And let that for double the rente
of the lande that was ſolde.
and ſaide if he woulde do:
he ſhoulde make of one penye two.
Marye that woulde I fayne do
lende but for a monethes day:
Wyth a plaine bill of ſale
if the day be not kept,
For the vſe of a ſhyllinge
lo I haue tolde you al ſens.
That heauen is no place,Pſal. xv.
but it is not youre calling.
and youre cattell in the leyes.
To the profite of all them
Ye are not borne to your ſelfe
where of God did you make.
Is a thinge that you ſhall
Luke. vi.Take hede leſt ye flytte
